title: Conquest of Bashan
shortSummary: Deuteronomy chapter 3 recounts the victorious conquest of King Og of Bashan and his territory by the Israelites under Moses' leadership. It highlights God's faithfulness in delivering enemies into Israel's hands and the division of the conquered land among the tribes, while also recording Moses' plea to enter the Promised Land and God's denial of that request.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Israelite wilderness wanderings just before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who directs the conquest of Bashan, distributes the land, and intercedes with God on behalf of the people.

keyCharacters.name: Og, King of Bashan
keyCharacters.description: The last of the Rephaim (giants) defeated by Israel; his defeat symbolizes God's power over formidable enemies.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ appointed successor who is charged to lead Israel into the Promised Land and to be strong and courageous.

keyCharacters.name: Jair
keyCharacters.description: A son of Manasseh who takes possession of the region of Argob and names it Bashanhavothjair.

definitions.definition: A term referring to a race of giants or mighty men in the ancient Near East, of which Og was one of the last survivors.
An ancient unit of length based on the forearm from elbow to fingertip, approximately 18 inches; used here to describe Og’s bed size.
A region in Bashan known for its many fortified cities, described as the land of giants.
A mountain peak from which Moses viewed the Promised Land before his death.

outline.heading: Victory over King Og and conquest of Bashan
outline.description: Israel defeats Og, king of Bashan, with God’s help, destroying his cities and capturing the land. This victory demonstrates God's power and faithfulness in fulfilling His promises.

outline.heading: Division of the conquered land
outline.description: Moses allocates the newly conquered territories to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh, establishing their inheritance east of the Jordan River.

outline.heading: Instructions for the tribes and encouragement for Joshua
outline.description: Moses commands the armed tribes to lead the conquest while their families remain in their cities, and encourages Joshua to be strong, assuring them that God will fight for Israel.

outline.heading: Moses’ plea to enter the Promised Land and God’s denial
outline.description: Moses earnestly asks God to allow him to enter the Promised Land, but God refuses, instructing him instead to view the land from Mount Pisgah and to commission Joshua.

outline.heading: Israel’s encampment opposite Bethpeor
outline.description: The chapter concludes with Israel settling in the valley opposite Bethpeor, poised to continue their conquest under Joshua’s leadership.

application: Trust in God's power to deliver you from seemingly insurmountable challenges, just as He delivered Israel from King Og.
Obey God's instructions faithfully, even when they require patience or waiting, as the tribes waited for their brethren to possess the land.
Encourage and strengthen others in leadership and faith, following Moses’ example with Joshua.
Accept God's sovereign will, even when it means personal disappointment, trusting His greater plan as Moses did when denied entry into the Promised Land.

keyVerses.text: Ye shall not fear them: for the LORD your God he shall fight for you.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reassures believers that God fights on their behalf, removing fear in the face of opposition.

keyVerses.text: O Lord GOD, thou hast begun to shew thy servant thy greatness, and thy mighty hand: for what God is there in heaven or in earth, that can do according to thy works, and according to thy might?
keyVerses.significance: Moses’ prayer acknowledges God's unmatched power and faithfulness, inspiring trust and worship.

keyVerses.text: But the LORD was wroth with me for your sakes, and would not hear me: and the LORD said unto me, Let it suffice thee; speak no more unto me of this matter.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's sovereign authority and the necessity of submitting to His will, even in difficult circumstances.

keyVerses.text: For only Og king of Bashan remained of the remnant of giants; behold, his bedstead was a bedstead of iron; is it not in Rabbath of the children of Ammon? nine cubits was the length thereof, and four cubits the breadth of it, after the cubit of a man.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the extraordinary nature of Og and God's power in defeating such a formidable foe.
